{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3224992,"name":"","username":"Mara1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/4af34b/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-08-15T13:30:06.754Z","cooked":"

Building an MK4i with Neos. How does the CANencoder get wired? Is it connected to the sparkmax? or does it get wired in the CAN bus? Thanks. (And if anyone has any general wiring tips for the MK4i with neos, that would be great, completely new at this, worked with falcons before).

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-08-15T13:30:06.754Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":185,"reads":406,"readers_count":405,"score":1006.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":439827,"topic_slug":"mk4i-swerve-with-neos","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44530,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mk4i-swerve-with-neos/439827/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3224993,"name":"","username":"SammyPants","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sammypants/{size}/188763_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-15T13:46:15.574Z","cooked":"

the cancoder will be attached to the can bus like it normally would

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-08-15T13:46:15.574Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":399,"readers_count":398,"score":109.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":439827,"topic_slug":"mk4i-swerve-with-neos","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51921,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3100 alum (old prog lead)"},"post_url":"/t/mk4i-swerve-with-neos/439827/2","custom_user_title":"3100 alum (old prog lead)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3224994,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-15T13:50:22.577Z","cooked":"

The Sparkmax can not interface with the cancoder. You need to hook it to the CAN bus, then your code should “initialize” the internal encoder on the sparkmax on startup to read that value then you can continue closed loop on the sparkmax. Another option is just running closed loop on the RIO closing on the cancoder value (a little more latency but will work ok).

The CANcoder should be connected to the CAN bus, same as before. No need to involve the Spark Max.

That said, if you wanted to avoid the CAN bus (and having to run power to each encoder) for some reason, you can use other encoder options to talk directly with the Spark Max.

For wiring tips my team played around with mounting the spark maxes on a 3d printed on the side of the swerve module. I couldn’t find the CAD but here is a good thread on 3d printed spark max mounts:

3D Printed mount for Spark Max / Neo Robot Showcase
If you are looking for a clean wiring solution for the MK4i w/Neos, I’ll add a shameless plug here for what the 4272 students designed. Kept wiring pretty clean. The other thing we are messing around with is using the TTB Encoders, which because they have analog outputs, can plug into the Spark Sax Dataport (gets rid of a ton of CAN wires if you go this route). Still messing around with that solution though. [image]
